metadata.title: Truxillic and truxinic acid-based, bio-derived diesters as potent internal donor in Ziegler-Natta catalyst for propylene polymerization

Truxillic and truxinic acid-based, bio-derived diesters as potent internal donor in Ziegler-Natta catalyst for propylene polymerization Akanksha Matta a Patchanee Chammingkwan a Brajendra K. Singh b Minoru Terano a Tatsuo Kaneko a Toshiaki Taniike a ⁎ a Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 1-1 Asahidai, Nomi, Ishikawa, 923-1292, Japan Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology 1-1 Asahidai Nomi Ishikawa 923-1292 Japan b Bioorganic Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110-007, India Bioorganic Laboratory Department of Chemistry University of Delhi Delhi 110-007 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In this study, novel α-truxillic and β-truxinic acid-based, bio-derived diesters have been developed as internal donors for preparing Ziegler-Natta (ZN) catalysts. Impacts of these bio-derived diesters were investigated on the chemical composition, the morphology, the mode of adsorption, and the propylene polymerization performance of the catalysts in comparison to the most widely used fourth-generation catalyst containing dibutyl phthalate. The molecular structures of the diesters and the particle morphology of the catalysts were preserved in the catalyst preparation. The bio-derived diesters afforded ZN catalysts with a reasonable activity and stereospecificity in propylene polymerization along with similarly broad molecular weight distribution (MWD) as the phthalate-based catalyst. Another promising feature of the catalysts was an opposite hydrogen response in terms of expansion of MWD upon the addition of H2. Keywords Bio-derived diester Internal donor Ziegler-Natta catalyst Propylene polymerization Hydrogen response Density functional calculation 1 Introduction The current industrial significance of polypropylene (PP) has been greatly driven by continuous advances in catalyst technologies and polymerization processes [1], in which the evolution of the heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta (ZN) catalyst has played the most important role [2,3]. The heterogeneous ZN catalyst for stereoselective propylene polymerization initiated from solid TiCl3 [4,5] combined with diethylaluminium chloride as an activator. Attempts to enhance the catalyst activity reached the invention of MgCl2-supported TiCl4 system with triethylaluminium in 1972, where the addition of ethyl benzoate in the solid catalyst as an internal donor (ID) and p-substituted ethyl benzoate in the activator system as an external donor (ED) was essential to provide sufficiently isotactic PP [6]. Since then, the main focus in the development of ZN catalysts has turned to the discovery of a new donor system. In 1977, the combination of phthalic diester (ID) and alkoxysilane (ED) was introduced to enhance the activity and the stereospecificity of the catalyst [7]. This catalyst, called the fourth-generation catalyst, has kept a dominant share in the industrial production of PP, while significant impacts of the choice of the donors on the catalyst performance as well as on the polymer properties have motivated further exploration. Specifically, recent environmental and health concerns of phthalates have boosted efforts to find phthalate-free donors [8,9]. In 1990′s, a new class of IDs such as 1,3-diethers [10] and malonate diesters [11] have been discovered. The resultant catalysts were generally featured with an activity and stereospecificity superior to those of the previous generation, but a narrow molecular weight distribution (MWD) of produced PP has limited their application only to specific grades. It was considered that the conformational rigidity of these donors (i.e. inflexible distance between two electron donating groups) restricts the adsorption modes that a donor molecule can adopt on MgCl2 surfaces. Subsequent efforts have paid attention on molecular structures bearing a longer spacer between two coordinating groups such as succinate diesters [12], glutarate diesters [13], or those with one ester group replaced by another electron donating group like ether, ketone, or amide [14]. Especially, the catalyst that contains a succinate diester with two chiral centres is recognized as the sixth-generation, affording PP with the broadest MWD [15]. The significance of the stereochemical structure of diester-type IDs was recently described for 5-norbornene-2,3-dicarboxylic acid diesters [16]. Likewise, the latter half of the history of the ZN catalyst has been illuminated by the appearance of new donors, and these efforts are still progressing with the expectation of the unseen seventh-generation. In an endeavour to develop a non-phthalate ID, structurally diverse and harmless electron donors that are derived from bio-based precursors are proposed in this study. Trans-cinnamic acid, a natural deaminated product of phenylalanine present in plant tissues, has a long history of human exposure as a key component of plant-derived scents and flavorings [17]. Also, there have been reports on the occurrence of a few secondary metabolites in plants that are photodimers of cinnamic acid, namely α-truxillic and β-truxinic acids [18]. They are non-hazardous and have flexible structures constituting a cyclobutane ring with four chiral centres, thus being attractive for the use as an ID in the ZN catalyst. Biological significance of trans-cinnamic, α-truxillic and β-truxinic acids has been widely studied in terms of anti-microbial [19], anti-inflammatory [20,21], anti-tumor [22], and antinociceptive effects [23]. However, the application of such a class of compounds in the ZN catalyst has not been reported to date. In this study, novel bio-derived diesters of α-truxillic and β-truxinic acids were synthesized via solid-state photodimerization of trans-cinnamic acid derivatives, and they were employed to prepare phthalate-free ZN catalysts. The propylene polymerization performance of these catalysts was compared with that of the fourth-generation catalyst in terms of the activity, the stereoregularity, and the MWD of PP in the presence or absence of H2. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All the reagents employed in this study were of research grades and used as delivered unless specified. Trans-cinnamic acid, cinnamoyl chloride, trimethylsilyl chloride (TMS-Cl), n-butanol and p-nitrophenol were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Co. Titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4), di-n-butyl phthalate (DBP) and sodium sulphate were supplied from Wako Pure Chemical Industries Ltd. Pyridine was purchased from Kanto Chemical Co., Inc. Tetrahydrofuran (THF), acetone, ethyl acetate, hexane, methanol, sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) were obtained from Sigma Aldrich. n-Heptane and toluene were dried over 4 Å molecular sieves with N2 bubbling prior to use. Triethylaluminium (TEA) as an activator for polymerization was donated by Tosoh Finechem Co. and used as a diluted solution in heptane. Propylene of a polymerization grade was donated by Japan Polypropylene Co. Diisopropyldimethoxysilane (DIPDMS), diisobutyldimethoxysilane (DIBDMS), dicyclopentyldimethoxysilane (DCPDMS), and cyclohexylmethyldimethoxysilane (CMDMS) were used as EDs after dilution with heptane. Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO-d6 ), chloroform-d (CDCl3), 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane-d2 , and 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane of analytical grades were used as delivered. 2.2 Synthesis of bio-derived donors 2.2.1 Synthesis of dibutyl 2,4-diphenylcyclobutane-1,3-dicarboxylate α-Truxillic acid (2) was synthesized via solid-state [2 + 2] photocycloaddition of trans-cinnamic acid (1), where a suspension of 1.0 g of the α-form of trans-cinnamic acid (recrystallized from benzene) in hexane (20 mL) was irradiated to a 100 W high-pressure Hg lamp (Omni Cure S2000, EXFO Photonic Solution Inc. with an intensity of 2.7 mW/cm3 and a 250–450 nm band-pass filter) for 24 h. After the completion of the reaction, the mixture was filtered to get a white solid in 65% yield, m.p. 287.0 °C (lit. m.p. 284–286 ºC) [24]. α-Truxillic acid (2) (500 mg, 1.68 mmol) was mixed with TMS-Cl (275.0 mg, 2.53 mmol) and n-butanol (6.6 mL, 2.86 mmol) in a microwave vial at room temperature, and the mixture was subjected to microwave irradiation (CEM-Discover-Coolmate monomode microwave apparatus operating at a frequency of 2.45 GHz) at 110 °C for 20 min. The progress of the reaction was monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC, 7/3 hexane/acetone). When the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, a crystalline solid precipitated out, which was vacuum filtered and dried. The compound 3 was obtained as a white crystalline solid in 83% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ): 0.74 (t, J = 7.34 Hz, 6 H, Ha), 0.99–1.11 (m, 4 H, Hb), 1.13–1.22 (m, 4 H, Hc), 3.59–3.67 (m, 2 H, Hd), 3.68–3.76 (m, 2 H, Hd), 3.93 (dd, J = 10.70, 7.15 Hz, 2 H, H1,3), 4.42 (dd, J = 10.64, 7.21 Hz, 2 H, H2,4), 7.17–7.25 (m, 4 H, Ar), 7.28–7.33 (m, 6 H, Ar) (Fig. S1a); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3, δ): 13.9, 19.2, 30.6, 41.8, 47.1, 64.7, 127.4, 127.9, 128.7, 139.2, 172.3 (Fig. S1b); HRMS (ESI) m/z: [M+H]+ calculated for C26H32O4, 409.23006; found, 409.23726. 2.2.2 Synthesis of dibutyl 3,4-diphenylcyclobutane-1,2-dicarboxylate The synthesis was accomplished in 4 steps based on literature with a few modifications [23]: 2.2.2.1 Synthesis of p-nitrophenyl cinnamate To a solution of p-nitrophenol (4) (500 mg, 3.6 mmol) and pyridine (158.0 mg, 2.0 mmol) in THF (5.0 mL), cinnamoyl chloride (599.0 mg, 3.6 mmol) in THF (0.50 mL) was added at 0–5 ºC, and the reaction mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 2 h. The reaction mixture was then poured into water (100 mL) and filtered off to give a white precipitate in 68% yield, m.p. 145.0 °C (lit. m.p. 145–146 °C) [25]. 2.2.2.2 Synthesis of β-truxinic acid bis(p-nitrophenyl)ester A solution of p-nitrophenyl cinnamate (6) (650 mg, 2.4 mmol) in hexane (10 mL) was irradiated to UV for 8 h in order to induce photodimerization to form β-truxinic acid bis(p-nitrophenyl)ester (7). After the completion of the reaction, the mixture was filtered to get a light-brown solid in 51% yield, m.p. 192.0 °C (lit. m.p. 192–193 ºC) [26]. 2.2.2.3 Synthesis of β-truxinic acid A solution of β-truxinic acid bis(p-nitrophenyl)ester (7) (600 mg, 1.1 mmol) and NaOH (312 mg, 7.8 mmol) in methanol (6.0 mL) was subjected to microwave irradiation at 70 °C for 25 min. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC analysis (7/3 hexane/acetone). After the completion of the reaction, pH was adjusted to 3 with HCl, followed by extraction with ethyl acetate. The combined organic extracts were dried over sodium sulphate, filtered and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by column chromatography (7/3 hexane/acetone) over silica gel to yield the desired product 8 in 47% yield, m.p. 205.0 °C (lit. m.p. 206–208 ºC) [27]. 2.2.2.4 Synthesis of dibutyl 3,4-diphenylcyclobutane-1,2-dicarboxylate β-Truxinic acid (8) (500 mg, 1.68 mmol) was mixed with TMS-Cl (275.0 mg, 2.53 mmol) and n-butanol (6.6 mL, 2.86 mmol) in a microwave vial at room temperature. The reaction mixture was subjected to microwave irradiation at 110 °C for 20 min. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC analysis (7/3 hexane/acetone). Subsequently, the reaction mixture was poured in water (30 mL), extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 30 mL), and the combined organic extracts were dried over sodium sulphate and dried in vacuo. The compound 9 was obtained as transparent oil in 85% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ): 0.94 (t, J = 7.34 Hz, 6 H, Ha), 1.33–1.44 (m, 4 H, Hb), 1.58–1.69 (m, 4 H, Hc), 3.82–3.85 (m, 2 H, H1,2), 4.09–4.20 (m, 4 H, Hd), 4.38–4.43 (m, 2 H, H3,4), 6.91–6.96 (m, 4 H, Ar), 7.04–7.13 (m, 6 H, Ar) (Fig. S2a); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3, δ): 13.9, 19.4, 30.9, 43.8, 45.2, 65.2, 126.6, 128.0, 128.2, 139.0, 172.8 (Fig. S2b); HRMS (ESI) m/z: [M+H]+ calculated for C26H32O, 409.23006; found, 409.23732. 2.3 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared based on a previously reported protocol [28]. 2.0 g of magnesium ethoxide (Mg(OEt)2) powder with spherical morphology and 12.0 mL of toluene were added in a parallel reactor equipped with a suspended magnetic stirrer under N2 atmosphere. 8.0 mL of a TiCl4 solution in toluene (1/1 v/v) was fed at a constant rate via a peristaltic pump, while the temperature of the suspension was kept at 0–5 ºC. Thereafter, the temperature was increased to 70 °C, followed by the addition of 1.0 mmol of a donor (dissolved in 2.0 mL of toluene). The reaction mixture was continuously stirred at 100 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, the reaction product was washed with toluene at 100 °C and further treated with 8.0 mL of a TiCl4 solution in toluene (1/1 v/v) and 1.0 mmol of a donor (dissolved in 2.0 mL toluene). The reaction mixture was stirred again for 1 h at 120 °C. The reaction product was washed with toluene at 100 °C and further treated with 8.0 mL of a TiCl4 solution in toluene (1/1 v/v) at 120 °C for 1 h. After that, the product was washed repetitively with toluene at 120 °C and heptane at room temperature to get the final catalyst. The synthesized catalyst was dried under vacuum and stored in a powder form under N2. 2.4 Propylene polymerization Propylene polymerization in slurry was performed in a 1 L stainless steel reactor equipped with a mechanical stirrer rotating at 350 rpm. Heptane (300 mL) was introduced in the reactor, followed by the addition of TEA (3.0 mmol) and an ED (0.30 mmol). The reactor was saturated with 0.5 MPa of propylene at 50 °C for 30 min prior to the addition of a catalyst (30 mg). When H2 was employed as a chain transfer agent, 4.0 or 16 mmol of H2 was injected immediately after the catalyst addition. Polymerization was carried out at 50 °C for 60 min, in which the propylene pressure was maintained at 0.5 MPa. The obtained polymer was filtered and dried in vacuum at 60 °C for 6 h. 2.5 Characterization The structure of the diesters 3 and 9 as well as the intermediate compounds was determined by 1H and 13C NMR (Bruker Avance III 400) operated at 400 and 100 MHz, respectively, and mass spectrometry (Bruker daltonics fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometer, magnet: 9.4 T, ionization method: ESI). The Ti content in the catalysts was determined by UV–vis spectroscopy (V-670 JASCO). A specified amount of a catalyst sample was dissolved in a HCl/H2SO4/H2O2 solution. The absorbance intensity of a ligand metal charge transfer band at 410 nm was used to determine the Ti content with the aid of an externally acquired standard curve. The donor content was determined by 1H NMR. A specified amount of a catalyst sample and 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane as an internal standard (for quantitative measurements) were dissolved in DMSO-d6 and transferred to a NMR tube under N2 atmosphere for the analysis. The morphology of catalyst particles was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-4100) operated at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. A catalyst sample was dispersed on a carbon tape under N2 atmosphere, and then subjected to Pt-Pd sputtering for 100 s prior to the measurement. The particle characteristics were quantified from the SEM micrographs using ImageJ software [29]. The pentad stereosequence of PP was measured by 13C NMR at 120 °C using 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane-d2 as an internal lock and reference. All the NMR spectra were processed by ACD/NMR processor academic edition. The chemical shift values and coupling constants (J) are reported in ppm (δ scale) and Hz, respectively. Abbreviations used are: s (singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), dd (double doublet) and m (multiplet). The melting temperature of PP was measured using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC 822, METTLER Co., Ltd). The M w/M n of PP was determined by high-temperature gel permeation chromatography (GPC, Waters 150C) equipped with polystyrene gel columns (Showa Denko AD806M/S) and an IR detector (MIRAN 1A) at 140 °C using o-dichlorobenzene as the eluent and calibrated with polystyrene standards. 2.6 Calculations Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to investigate the adsorption ability of IDs on representative MgCl2 surfaces in different modes. The full detail of the calculation method was described elsewhere [30,31]. In brief, the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [32] of generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was employed as the exchange-correlation functional, and valence and core electrons were respectively described using DNP [33] and effective core potentials [34,35]. All the calculations were implemented using a program package DMol3 [33]. Three modes of the adsorption were considered in this study: chelate and bridging adsorption on the (110) surface, and bridging adsorption on the (100) surface, in which the (110) and (100) surfaces were expressed as slab models using p(2 × 3) and p(4 × 1) unit cells, respectively. The most stable rotational conformation was chosen for each of the IDs and adsorption modes. The energy of the adsorption was reported as the differential energy before and after the adsorption. For the sake of computational brevity, dibutyl esters were replaced by the corresponding diethyl esters [36]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of donors The synthetic routes to novel diesters, i.e. dibutyl 2,4-diphenylcyclobutane-1,3-dicarboxylate (3) and dibutyl 3,4-diphenylcyclobutane-1,2-dicarboxylate (9), have been outlined in Schemes Scheme 1 and Scheme 2 , respectively. The synthesis of 3 involved solid-state photodimerization of recrystallized trans-cinnamic acid (α-cinnamic acid, 1) to form  α-truxillic acid (2), followed by esterification using n-butanol (Scheme Scheme 1). Many attempts failed to synthesize β-truxinic acid (8) directly from trans-cinnamic acid as the β-form of cinnamic acid (precursor of β-truxinic acid) was hardly obtained. Thus, the synthesis of 9 was performed through an intermediate compound 7, which involved four reaction steps (Scheme Scheme 2) [23]. The synthesis started with the reaction of p-nitrophenol (4) and cinnamoyl chloride (5) to form the corresponding ester 6. The ester 6 was photodimerized to form β-truxinic acid bis(p-nitrophenyl)ester (7), followed by hydrolysis of the ester group by a strong base to yield β-truxinic acid (8). Lastly, the esterification was carried out in order to produce dibutyl 3,4-diphenylcyclobutane-1,2-dicarboxylate (9) in very good yield. The structure of both the diesters 3 and 9 was confirmed by NMR and mass spectrometry. 3.2 Catalyst preparation All the catalyst samples were prepared based on a chemical method using spherical Mg(OEt)2 as a support precursor. The diesters 3 and 9 were respectively utilized as IDs to prepare Cat 1 and Cat 2. Cat 3 was prepared using an equimolar mixture of the diesters 3 and 9. In addition, Cat 4 was prepared as a reference under the same conditions using DBP as an ID. The list of the catalyst samples and their chemical compositions are described in Table 1 . 1H NMR spectroscopy was employed to understand the structure and the content of donors in the catalysts. The spectra displayed multiple resonances corresponding to the donor structure (Figs. S3–S6). The double doublets at 3.87 and 4.29 ppm, the multiplets at 3.86 and 4.17 ppm in Cat 1 and Cat 2 were respectively assigned to methine (CH) protons of the cyclobutane ring. The presence of resonances corresponding to the methyl (CH3) and methylene (CH2) protons of the butyl ester moiety was also seen in the spectra (Figs. S3–S5). This indicated that the molecular structure of the diesters was preserved during the catalyst preparation. The integral intensities of the CH protons of the cyclobutane ring were used to quantify the donor content in the catalyst samples. The integral intensity of 1,1,2,2-tetrchloroethane resonance at 7.00 ppm was used as standard for quantification. Cat 3 contained both of the diesters 3 and 9 in a comparable amount, suggesting that these donors were adsorbed similarly strongly to the MgCl2 surfaces. The DBP content in Cat 4 was quantified using the integral intensity of OCH2 observed at 4.15 ppm (Fig. S6) [37]. In addition to the resonances arising from IDs, all catalysts exhibited the resonances at 3.38 and 0.99 ppm, which were assigned to H2 and H3 protons of the ethoxy group, respectively. It is most plausible that this ethoxy group was derived from Ti(OEt)xCl4−x as a by-product of chlorination of Mg(OEt)2 with TiCl4. The presence of the ethoxy residual in the final catalyst accompanied a higher Ti content in Cat 1–3 as compared to Cat 4. A lower donor content (in mol) with respect to a higher Ti content was plausibly due to molecular bulkiness of the diesters 3 and 9 [38]. A rather low Ti content and hence the low ethoxy content in Cat 4 compared to literature should come from repetitive titanation at a higher temperature [39]. These results indicated that the chemical composition of the catalysts was affected by the structure of IDs. The morphology of catalyst particles was observed using SEM and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . All the catalysts retained spherical morphology of Mg(OEt)2 without forming fine or agglomerated particles. Their surfaces were composed by platelet building units as usual for Mg(OEt)2-based catalysts. The size distributions of the catalyst particles were almost identical among each other (Table 2 ). It was clear that the bio-derived diesters do not interfere with the morphological replication in the catalyst preparation. 3.3 Polymerization performance In order to evaluate the performance of the novel bio-derived diesters as IDs, propylene polymerization was conducted, first in the absence of H2, where four kinds of typical EDs were employed for each of the catalysts. The results are summarized in Table 3 . It was found that the activity followed the sequence of Cat 4 > Cat 2 > Cat 3 > Cat 1 irrespective of the EDs. The order of the activity was inversely correlated with the ethoxy or Ti content of the catalysts (Table 1). In literature, it was reported that the residual ethoxy content sensitively damages the catalyst activity in propylene polymerization [40], and we found a similar conclusion that the activity per Ti was decreased exponentially to the ethoxy content (Fig. 2 ). It meant that lower activities for the bio-derived donors compared to DBP or the lower activity for the diester 3 compared to 9 resulted merely from the chemical composition of the catalysts rather than from the molecular structure of these donors themselves. The presence of inactive (or poisonous) by-products formed during the chemical interaction of Mg(OEt)2 with TiCl4, especially TiCl3(OEt) are known to decrease not only the activity but also the stereoregularity [41]. Indeed, the melting temperature and the mesopentad mole fraction (mmmm) of produced PP tended to become lower as the ethoxy content in the catalysts was higher (Table 4 ). Nonetheless, it must be stressed that the novel bio-derived diesters basically afforded isotactic PP with a reasonable stereoregularity. For the employed four types of the EDs, the order of the stereoregularity followed DCPDMS ∼ DIPDMS > DIBDMS > CMDMS irrespective of the IDs. It is well known that the alkyl substituents with braches at the Cα position tend to enhance the stereospecificity of the catalysts [42], and in this light, the bio-derived diesters responded similarly to DBP. Table 5 demonstrates the molecular weight and its distribution of PP prepared using DIPDMS as the ED. It was observed that the molecular weight of PP prepared by Cat 1–3 was all lower than that prepared by Cat 4. As it is known that active sites with higher stereospecificity tend to accompany a greater propagation rate constant (k p) [43], the order of the molecular weight was believed as a consequence of lower stereospecificity of Cat 1–3 as compared to that of Cat 4. Meanwhile, the MWD curves of PP obtained by Cat 1–4 were all bimodal (Fig. 3 ) so that the M w/M n value of 4.1–4.6 for Cat 1–3 was comparably broad to 4.4 for Cat 4. In the case of MgCl2-supported ZN catalysts, the polydispersity of produced polymer is usually associated with the multisite nature of active sites, and the type of adsorption modes that a donor molecule can adopt on MgCl2 surfaces is believed to be relevant to it. For instance, it has been considered that 1,3-diether leads to narrow MWD as its short spacer limits the available adsorption mode to the chelate mode on the MgCl2 (110) surface, and diesters like phthalates or succinates that give broader MWD can also adopt bridging modes on the (110) and (100) surfaces [30]. In this light, we have performed DFT calculations to investigate representative adsorption modes that the bio-derived diesters can also adopt on MgCl2 (110) and (100) surfaces. Three adsorption modes were considered, that are: i) chelate adsorption on the (110) surface, in which two ester groups bind to one four-fold coordinated Mg2+ site, ii) bridging adsorption between two neighbouring four-fold coordinated Mg2+ sites on the (110) surface, and iii) bridging adsorption between two neighbouring five-fold coordinated Mg2+ sites on the (100) surface. The distance required for these adsorption modes becomes greater in the order of chelate mode on (110) > bridging mode on (100) > bridging mode on (110). The optimized structures and corresponding adsorption energies are shown in Fig. 4 and Table 6 . The bio-derived diesters most preferred the bridging adsorption on the (110) surface, and their adsorption energies were much greater than that of diethyl phthalate (DEP) because of the more electron donating backbones in the structure. In the case of DEP, two carboxylic esters share one phenyl ring, while the bio-derived donors possess one phenyl ring per ester, similar to ethyl benzoate (EB). The adsorption energy for EB was reported as ca. −30 kcal mol–1 [30], thus the absorption energy of ca. −60 kcal mol–1 for the bio-derived donors was somewhat reasonable. On the other hand, the presence of the longer spacer and/or the steric bulkiness for the bio-derived donors tended to reduce the adsorption energies for the adsorption modes that require a shorter distance. In contrast to the fact that the three modes gave comparable adsorption energies for DEP, the adsorption energies for the bio-derived donors decreased in the order of chelate mode on (110) < bridging mode on (100) < bridging mode on (110). Specifically, the diester 3 was found not to adopt the chelate mode on the (110) surface due to its longest spacer length as well as due to the opposing orientation of the two ester groups. Apart from the higher adsorption energies for the bio-derived donors, such steric restriction due to the molecular bulkiness was thought to be more important for the experimental outcome that the coverages of the diesters 3 and 9 were lower than that of DBP. 3.4 Hydrogen response H2 is a chain transfer agent that is most commonly used in industry to regulate the molecular weight of polyolefin. A catalyst is required to possess higher hydrogen response without sacrificing the M w/M n value of the produced polymer in order to balance the flowability in melt and the mechanical strength in solid. The choice of donors is the most crucial parameter to determine these catalytic properties. The performance of the bio-derived diesters was evaluated in terms of the hydrogen response of the catalysts by performing propylene polymerization at two different concentrations of H2 using DIPDMS as an ED. The results of the activity and polymer characteristics are summarized in Table 7 . As usual for the MgCl2-supported ZN catalysts over the fourth-generation, the addition of H2 improved the activity and (slightly) stereorespecificity of the catalysts, and this phenomenon was more or less observed for the bio-derived diesters. In the case of DBP (Cat 4), the addition of 16 mmol of H2 reduced the M n and M w values into 46% and 38% with respect to those obtained in the absence of H2. The greater impact of H2 to a higher molecular-weight fraction explains the shrinkage of the M w/M n value by the addition of H2. In contrast to this usual response, it was found that the bio-derived diesters gave the opposite response to the catalysts. The addition of H2 impacted more strongly to a lower molecular-weight fraction, e.g. the M n and M w values were respectively reduced into 31% and 35% for 3, and 24% and 30% for 9 by the addition of the same amount of H2. Due to this peculiar response, the bio-derived diesters afforded PP with broader MWD in the presence of H2 (see Fig. 3 also), which is the most promising characteristic we found for the newly developed donors. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we have developed two novel diesters that are used as internal donors in Ziegler-Natta (ZN) catalysts for propylene polymerization. The new donors are bio-derived and absolutely non-hazardous to humans and the environment. Three catalysts were prepared using the new bio-derived diesters and the effect of these diesters on the performance of the resultant catalysts and polypropylene properties were studied. The new diesters were applicable to the chemical reaction-based preparation of ZN catalysts without destructing the particle morphology as well as their molecular structure. The obtained catalysts offered a reasonable activity and stereospecificity in propylene polymerization, and the molecular weight distribution (MWD) of PP was similarly broad to that given by the fourth-generation catalyst. In general, non-phthalate diesters (especially for broad MWD) tend to give lower activities compared with phthalate. For instance, a typical activity of the sixth-generation catalysts with succinate diesters is about half of that of the fourth-generation catalysts in propylene polymerization. In this light, the activities of the catalysts derived from the novel bio-derived diesters are not necessarily regarded as low in an industrial point of view. Moreover, the bio-derived diesters led to broader MWD in the presence of H2, while most of non-phthalate diesters suffer from the opposite response (i.e. narrower MWD). We believe that this finding is highly useful for directing the industrial development of new non-phthalate donors. coredata.dc:description: In this study, novel α-truxillic and β-truxinic acid-based, bio-derived diesters have been developed as internal donors for preparing Ziegler-Natta (ZN) catalysts. Impacts of these bio-derived diesters were investigated on the chemical composition, the morphology, the mode of adsorption, and the propylene polymerization performance of the catalysts in comparison to the most widely used fourth-generation catalyst containing dibutyl phthalate. The molecular structures of the diesters and the particle morphology of the catalysts were preserved in the catalyst preparation. The bio-derived diesters afforded ZN catalysts with a reasonable activity and stereospecificity in propylene polymerization along with similarly broad molecular weight distribution (MWD) as the phthalate-based catalyst. Another promising feature of the catalysts was an opposite hydrogen response in terms of expansion of MWD upon the addition of H2.
coredata.dc:title: Truxillic and truxinic acid-based, bio-derived diesters as potent internal donor in Ziegler-Natta catalyst for propylene polymerization
